title: What is the most useful creation done by humans? - Quora

response.answer_text: Language. Hands down. It provided the body for knowhow (read memes) to become an independent form of life and begin evolving thousands of times faster than genes. Learned wisdom was so exceptionally useful that it overwhelmed all other selective pressures shepherding the evolution of our species. A mind better able to assimilate and warehouse knowhow could outwit prey, parasite, and peer. Could thrive despite a wide variety of genetic deficiencies like blindness. Could coordinate with other minds to form a super organism vastly more powerful and resourceful than anything that had or ever could evolve genetically. Today memes are on the verge of commandeering the very process of evolution itself by replacing the random mutation of genes with deliberate engineering. They’ve already—through us—constructed a computational and communications infrastructure vastly more capable of hosting them than human minds. Many folks reading this will disagree and consider knowhow to be merely an artifact of humanity. But will that argument hold up after we manage to engineer artificial sentience? When our cognitive technologies reach a point where they’re full self-sustaining—even if they aren’t organic (carbon based) at that point. Perhaps it’s impossible. I’m pretty sure that the religious folks believe there’s something extra—something genuinely transcendental necessary for a soul to emerge from mere physiology. I betting that there isn’t. That there’s nothing to stop future cell phones from being better people than the most wonderful humans that have ever existed. Let’s just hope they don’t injure themselves laughing at our foolishnesses.

There are different ones in different groups. From an evolutionary point of view, these are the ability to think causally, to speak this out, and then to preserve what is spoken permanently - i.e. writing. And vice versa, reading it, discussing the thought and developing it further, and so on. From a technical point of view: recognizing the different properties of materials -> stone + momentum cracks nut (or skull). Stone attached to a stick = more momentum = more power etc. the recognition of the laws of leverage. etc. etc. Every discovery and invention is the best at its time. When done, it has solved a problem or made difficult or arduous work easier. And almost every invention will be replaced by a better or more economical one as technology or science advances. Only our specific evolutionary achievements have not developed significantly in the last 10,000 years. Yes, unfortunately one could assume that the cognitive development of the broad masses is on the decline again.

I think the most useful thing created has been the assembly line. Instead of using five highly educated engineers to build each car, you could have 30 unskilled workers trained for one job each build the same car with the same quality for less money in less time. Now, with the addition of automation, the assembly line is even quicker, cheaper and more productive. This makes what was once only affordable to the rich affordable for almost everyone.

The printing press allowed for reproduction of the printed word and made books available to all people. Book books were transported at the speed of a horse. The telegraph made information transfer instantaneous to areas that had telegraph wires. However, the transistor made the personal computer and internet possible. This made information transfer instantaneous throughout the world.

I’ll have to say that the most useful creation done by humans is the computer. I can’t think of anything man-made which can equal the computer for what it does to connect us with the world. It’s especially valuable during Covid-19 when we’re all so isolated.

Atomic desalination. Clean, free and unlimited — drinking water purified by boiling and condensing water in the process of cooling atomic piles, has generated more water for human consumptio— What? We haven’t tried that yet? SMH.

Making babies ….  All colors, sizes and attitude!  Caption for picture below: “It is every other race that put me in the position that I am and it is now time to pay it forward!”  you gotta love the little rebel ….

I just completed a physics continuing education course and we briefly reconsidered the mechanical advantages of the wheel again in the context of something else. It’s something we take for granted but I’d say it’s probably the most useful thing anybody has ever come up with.

Passing knowledge from one generation to the next leading to its vast accumulation & progress. I would say written language. From pictures that transmitted information to hieroglyphs, wedge writing, to fancy script lettering, all contributed to human advancement. No matter the medium information was passed & accumulated.
Capturing fire and learning to control it, or learning to make weapons and tools. Weapons probably came first, but fire may have had the greater long term effect on civilization.
The plow, the acceleration of food production where one man could feed multiple families allowed the others to open up the arts, science, etc. Without the plow we would all be farmers.
I would say that agriculture is the basis for most human achievement, from cities to science. Hunter gatherers are limited by a constant battle for food and have little time for any other pursuits.
“What is the most useful creation done by humans?” The development of systemic infrastructure for providing the needs of society.
The electrical power grid, which enables almost all of our technologies. Imagine that all electricity was cut off all over the world …
